Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 3D X-Ray Computed Tomography Scanner for Imaging of Large Size Infrastructure, Biological, and Mechanical Components

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
X-ray computed tomography (CT) allows researchers to see inside structural, mechanical, electronic or biological parts and produce high-resolution 3D images of the parts, inside and out. This technology has evolved to enable X-ray CT scanning of larger parts made from denser materials while achieving high resolution at fast scan times. These advances have made x-ray CT a unique tool for researchers in disciplines from civil engineering to biology. This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of an advanced X-ray CT scanner capable of scanning parts as large as 1.2 meters tall and 0.84 meters wide at very high resolutions. A multidisciplinary team of University of Washington (UW) researchers has been assembled to acquire the instrument, including researchers from civil engineering, mechanical engineering, aeronautical engineering, anthropology, the Washington Nanofabrication Facility (WNF)/Electrical Engineering, biology, earth and space sciences, material science, and the Burke Museum which is a natural history and cultural museum on the campus of the University of Washington. The research enabled by this instrument is as broad and multidisciplinary as the research team and it will help to drive innovations in these diverse disciplines.

The imaging capability provided by the x-ray CT will allow structural engineering researchers to perform tests of large-scale structural subassemblages and then image the key components following the tests; enabling discovery of damage not visible from the surface. X-ray CT will be used to monitor damage progression in reinforced concrete bond zones, improving understanding and modeling of bond zone behavior. Researchers in composite structures used in aero, mechanical and civil applications will image composite components to investigate barely visible and subsurface defects, and failure initiation. These data will help develop and validate numerical models that rely on accurate characterization of voids and variations in fiber angles across laminate layers, advance composite micromechanics and failure theories for composites, and improve bond quality. Researchers in 3D printing will use the X-ray CT for nondestructive inspection of both internal and external geometry of 3D printed parts. They will also explore the effectiveness of X-ray CT evaluation of spatially controlled material composition of the 3D printed parts which is not otherwise feasible. Researchers in biological systems will image large portions of skeletal remains, fossils, and recently deceased animals to determine exact geometries; these data will enable the development of bio-mechanical models and investigation of the function of biological structures. Researchers in electrical engineering and nanofabrication will use the instrument in failure analysis of electronics fabricated with advanced techniques. The instrument will become a key piece of research infrastructure for the University of Washington and the Pacific Northwest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in the acquisition of a dual source X-ray Computed Tomography (CT) Scanner at the University of Washington (UW) to support research in numerous disciplines and facilitate interdisciplinary research collaborations. X-ray CT scanning provides a wide-range of disciplines with accurate measurements on the surface and inside of complex objects. The acquired scanner is able to serve a wide-range of disciplines because of its versatility. Its two X-ray sources enable ultra high-resolution imaging of less-dense materials (such as aerospace composites) as well as imaging of much more dense materials. Its industrial scale allows imaging of objects as large as 1.22 meters tall by 0.84 meters wide, serving the needs of biologists for scanning large fossils, skeletons, and specimens, and structural engineers for scanning building and bridge components for non-surface damage after they were tested in the UW Structural Research Laboratory.

During the grant period, the team of PIs and Senior Personnel from civil engineering, mechanical engineering, aeronautical engineering, anthropology the Washington Nanofabrication Facility (WNF)/Electrical Engineering, biology, earth and space sciences, material science and engineering, and the Burke Museum developed specifications for the X-ray CT scanner, led renovation of key space in the department of civil and environmental engineering to house the scanner, developed a broad interdisciplinary user-base, established a plan for continued scanner operations (including maintenance) and oversaw the training of four UW technicians from different departments on the safe operation of the scanner. Those actions ensure that the scanner will continue serve research needs and enable research advances long past the end of the grant period.

Below, selected examples of the advances and intellectual merit afforded by the scanner for different disciplines during its 1.5 year-long commissioning process are provided.

  • Biology: The scanner has been used to image large and sensitive fossils still in their substrate in support of two other NSF research grants [EAR-1337569 (Collaborative Research: Restructuring of terrestrial environments following the Permian-Triassic mass extinction; C.A. Sidor, PI) and EAR-1325674 (Collaborative Research: Taphonomy, paleoecology, and evolution of mammals and squamates from Egg Mountain: An exceptional view of a Late Cretaceous ecosystem; G.P. Wilson, PI] (Figures 1 and 2 show examples)
  • Aeronautics/Astronautics and Mechanical Engineering: The scanner has been used to identify damage in composite plates created with a new method of composites manufacturing. Figure 3 shows a composite plate with a circular hole and damage due to tensile loading.
  • Structural Engineering: The scanner has been used to identify imperfections in welded joints to help verify novel field damage detection techniques. Figure 4 shows an identified weld defect.
  • Mechanical Engineering/Optics: The scanner has been used to provide benchmarking for the development of new measurement methods for inspection of parts produced with advanced additive manufacturing (3D printing). Figure 5 shows an example scan of a 3D printed sinus cavity.

The CT scanner has improved the research infrastructure of the University of Washington and has catalyzed interdisciplinary research and learning.  In addition to providing a new significant research tool for the UW, this project has also advanced the skill set of graduate student and post-doctoral researchers. To date, the technical staff have trained ten graduate students and post-doctoral researchers in the scanner operation, basic radiography, image processing, and measurement concepts. These skills will improve the quality of their research in the future and their competitiveness for research positions. Thus, this Major Research Instrumentation grant has had significant impact on human resource development despite having no financial support for students. 


Last Modified: 10/18/2017
Modified by: Jeffrey W Berman

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. Fossilized skull of pre-mammalian species, embedded in low density substrate. CT scan clearly distinguished bone from matrix.

    Christian Sidor

    Jeffrey W Berman
    Figure 2
  • Figure 3. Close up of carbon composite test specimen, loaded axially to 90% max capacity. Two failures can be seen as dark vertical lines near the right and left margins of the hole.
    Anthony Waas
    Public Domain
    Jeffrey W Berman
    Figure 3
  • Figure 4. Defect in a welded joint. Small inclusion noted midway up the specimen on the right side.
    Dawn Lehman
    Public Domain

    Figure 4
  • Figure 5. 3D-printed sinus cavity. Scanned to check for internal defects and accuracy of print vs. original CT scan.
    Eric Seibel
    Copyrighted

X-ray CT scanning provides a wide-range of disciplines with accurate measurements on the surface and inside of complex objects. Mechanical Engineering/Optics: The scanner has been used to provide benchmarking for the development of new measurement methods for inspection of parts produced with advanced additive manufacturing (3D printing). To date, the technical staff have trained ten graduate students and post-doctoral researchers in the scanner operation, basic radiography, image processing, and measurement concepts. These skills will improve the quality of their research in the future and their competitiveness for research positions.
